lines.text: Enter GEORGE BEVIS and JOHN HOLLAND

lines.speaker: bevis
lines.text: Come, and get thee a sword, though made of a lath; they have been up these two days.

lines.speaker: holland
lines.text: They have the more need to sleep now, then.

lines.speaker: bevis
lines.text: I tell thee, Jack Cade the clothier means to dress the commonwealth, and turn it, and set a new nap upon it.

lines.speaker: holland
lines.text: So he had need, for 'tis threadbare. Well, I say it was never merry world in England since gentlemen came up.

lines.speaker: bevis
lines.text: O miserable age! virtue is not regarded in handicrafts-men.

lines.speaker: holland
lines.text: The nobility think scorn to go in leather aprons.

lines.speaker: bevis
lines.text: Nay, more, the king's council are no good workmen.

lines.speaker: holland
lines.text: True; and yet it is said, labour in thy vocation; which is as much to say as, let the magistrates be labouring men; and therefore should we be magistrates.

lines.speaker: bevis
lines.text: Thou hast hit it; for there's no better sign of a brave mind than a hard hand.

lines.speaker: holland
lines.text: I see them! I see them! there's Best's son, the tanner of Wingham,--

lines.speaker: bevis
lines.text: He shall have the skin of our enemies, to make dog's-leather of.

lines.speaker: holland
lines.text: And Dick the Butcher,--

lines.speaker: bevis
lines.text: Then is sin struck down like an ox, and iniquity's throat cut like a calf.

lines.speaker: holland
lines.text: And Smith the weaver,--

lines.speaker: bevis
lines.text: Argo, their thread of life is spun.

lines.speaker: holland
lines.text: Come, come, let's fall in with them.
Drum. Enter CADE, DICK the Butcher, SMITH the Weaver, and a Sawyer, with infinite numbers

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: We John Cade, so termed of our supposed father,--

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: [Aside]  Or rather, of stealing a cade of herrings.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: For our enemies shall fall before us, inspired with the spirit of putting down kings and princes, --Command silence.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: Silence!

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: My father was a Mortimer,--

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: [Aside]  He was an honest man, and a good bricklayer.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: My mother a Plantagenet,--

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: [Aside]  I knew her well; she was a midwife.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: My wife descended of the Lacies,--

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: [Aside]  She was, indeed, a pedler's daughter, and sold many laces.

lines.speaker: smith
lines.text: [Aside]  But now of late, notable to travel with her furred pack, she washes bucks here at home.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Therefore am I of an honourable house.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: [Aside]  Ay, by my faith, the field is honourable; and there was he borne, under a hedge, for his father had never a house but the cage.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Valiant I am.

lines.speaker: smith
lines.text: [Aside]  A' must needs; for beggary is valiant.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: I am able to endure much.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: [Aside]  No question of that; for I have seen him whipped three market-days together.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: I fear neither sword nor fire.

lines.speaker: smith
lines.text: [Aside]  He need not fear the sword; for his coat is of proof.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: [Aside]  But methinks he should stand in fear of fire, being burnt i' the hand for stealing of sheep.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Be brave, then; for your captain is brave, and vows reformation. There shall be in England seven halfpenny loaves sold for a penny: the three-hooped pot; shall have ten hoops and I will make it felony to drink small beer: all the realm shall be in common; and in Cheapside shall my palfrey go to grass: and when I am king, as king I will be,--

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: God save your majesty!

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: I thank you, good people: there shall be no money; all shall eat and drink on my score; and I will apparel them all in one livery, that they may agree like brothers and worship me their lord.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Nay, that I mean to do. Is not this a lamentable thing, that of the skin of an innocent lamb should be made parchment? that parchment, being scribbled o'er, should undo a man? Some say the bee stings: but I say, 'tis the bee's wax; for I did but seal once to a thing, and I was never mine own man since. How now! who's there?
Enter some, bringing forward the Clerk of Chatham

lines.speaker: smith
lines.text: The clerk of Chatham: he can write and read and cast accompt.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: O monstrous!

lines.speaker: smith
lines.text: We took him setting of boys' copies.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Here's a villain!

lines.speaker: smith
lines.text: Has a book in his pocket with red letters in't.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Nay, then, he is a conjurer.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: Nay, he can make obligations, and write court-hand.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: I am sorry for't: the man is a proper man, of mine honour; unless I find him guilty, he shall not die. Come hither, sirrah, I must examine thee: what is thy name?

lines.speaker: clerk
lines.text: Emmanuel.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: They use to write it on the top of letters: 'twill go hard with you.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Let me alone. Dost thou use to write thy name? or hast thou a mark to thyself, like an honest plain-dealing man?

lines.speaker: clerk
lines.text: Sir, I thank God, I have been so well brought up that I can write my name.

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: He hath confessed: away with him! he's a villain and a traitor.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Away with him, I say! hang him with his pen and ink-horn about his neck.
Exit one with the Clerk
Enter MICHAEL

lines.speaker: michael
lines.text: Where's our general?

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Here I am, thou particular fellow.

lines.speaker: michael
lines.text: Fly, fly, fly! Sir Humphrey Stafford and his brother are hard by, with the king's forces.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Stand, villain, stand, or I'll fell thee down. He shall be encountered with a man as good as himself: he is but a knight, is a'?

lines.speaker: michael
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: To equal him, I will make myself a knight presently. Rise up Sir John Mortimer. Now have at him!
Kneels
Rises
Enter SIR HUMPHREY and WILLIAM STAFFORD, with drum and soldiers

lines.speaker: sir humphrey
lines.text: Rebellious hinds, the filth and scum of Kent, Mark'd for the gallows, lay your weapons down; Home to your cottages, forsake this groom: The king is merciful, if you revolt.

lines.speaker: william stafford
lines.text: But angry, wrathful, and inclined to blood, If you go forward; therefore yield, or die.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: As for these silken-coated slaves, I pass not: It is to you, good people, that I speak, Over whom, in time to come, I hope to reign; For I am rightful heir unto the crown.

lines.speaker: sir humphrey
lines.text: Villain, thy father was a plasterer; And thou thyself a shearman, art thou not?

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: And Adam was a gardener.

lines.speaker: william stafford
lines.text: And what of that?

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Marry, this: Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March. Married the Duke of Clarence' daughter, did he not?

lines.speaker: sir humphrey
lines.text: Ay, sir.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: By her he had two children at one birth.

lines.speaker: william stafford
lines.text: That's false.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Ay, there's the question; but I say, 'tis true: The elder of them, being put to nurse, Was by a beggar-woman stolen away; And, ignorant of his birth and parentage, Became a bricklayer when he came to age: His son am I; deny it, if you can.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: Nay, 'tis too true; therefore he shall be king.

lines.speaker: smith
lines.text: Sir, he made a chimney in my father's house, and the bricks are alive at this day to testify it; therefore deny it not.

lines.speaker: sir humphrey
lines.text: And will you credit this base drudge's words, That speaks he knows not what?

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Ay, marry, will we; therefore get ye gone.

lines.speaker: william stafford
lines.text: Jack Cade, the Duke of York hath taught you this.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: [Aside]  He lies, for I invented it myself. Go to, sirrah, tell the king from me, that, for his father's sake, Henry the Fifth, in whose time boys went to span-counter for French crowns, I am content he shall reign; but I'll be protector over him.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: And furthermore, well have the Lord Say's head for selling the dukedom of Maine.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: And good reason; for thereby is England mained, and fain to go with a staff, but that my puissance holds it up. Fellow kings, I tell you that that Lord Say hath gelded the commonwealth, and made it an eunuch: and more than that, he can speak French; and therefore he is a traitor.

lines.speaker: sir humphrey
lines.text: O gross and miserable ignorance!

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: Nay, answer, if you can: the Frenchmen are our enemies; go to, then, I ask but this: can he that speaks with the tongue of an enemy be a good counsellor, or no?

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: No, no; and therefore we'll have his head.

lines.speaker: william stafford
lines.text: Well, seeing gentle words will not prevail, Assail them with the army of the king.

lines.speaker: sir humphrey
lines.text: Herald, away; and throughout every town Proclaim them traitors that are up with Cade; That those which fly before the battle ends May, even in their wives' and children's sight, Be hang'd up for example at their doors: And you that be the king's friends, follow me.
Exeunt WILLIAM STAFFORD and SIR HUMPHREY, and soldiers

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: And you that love the commons, follow me. Now show yourselves men; 'tis for liberty. We will not leave one lord, one gentleman: Spare none but such as go in clouted shoon; For they are thrifty honest men, and such As would, but that they dare not, take our parts.

lines.speaker: dick
lines.text: They are all in order and march toward us.

lines.speaker: cade
lines.text: But then are we in order when we are most out of order. Come, march forward. Where's Dick, the butcher of Ashford?
Exeunt
